Name: Galileo Galilei
Rationale: For systemic use of experimentation in science and contributions to scientific method, physics and observational astronomy

Name: Thales
Rationale: Attempted to explain natural phenomena without recourse to mythology

Name: Aristotle
Rationale: His contributions to the field include vast quantities of information about the variety, structure, and behavior of animals

Name: Robert Koch
Rationale: First to produce precise, correct descriptions of bacteria.

Name: Alfred Russel Wallace
Rationale: "... Often described as the Father of Biogeography, Wallace shows the impact of human activity on the natural world."[6]

Name: Margaret Oakley Dayhoff
Rationale: "... the mother and father of bioinformatics", according to David J. Lipman, former director of the National Center for Biotechnology Information.[7]

Name: Otto Brunfels
Rationale: The three German fathers of botany.[8][9]

Name: Carl Linnaeus
Rationale: Linnaeus founded an early branch of ecology that he called The Economy of Nature (1772), Haeckel coined the term "ecology" (German: Oekologie, Ökologie) (1866), Warming authored the first book on plant ecology. Plantesamfund (1895).

Name: Johan Christian Fabricius
Rationale: Fabricius described and published information on over 10,000 insects and refined Linnaeus's system of classification.

Name: Nikolaas Tinbergen
Rationale: The modern discipline of ethology is generally considered to have begun during the 1930s with the work of Nikolaas Tinbergen, Konrad Lorenz and Karl von Frisch, joint awardees of the 1973 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.[20]

Name: Charles Darwin
Rationale: On the Origin of Species (1859).

Name: Gregor Mendel
Rationale: For his study of the inheritance of traits in pea plants, which forms the basis for Mendelian inheritance[25]

Name: William Bateson
Rationale: Proponent of Mendelism.[26]

Name: Élie Metchnikoff
Rationale: Coined the term "gerontology" (1903). He was the first to perform systematic research on the effects of certain foods on lifespan and healthspan, developed the concept of probiotic diet that promotes long healthy life.[27][28][29][30][31][32][33]

Name: John Edwards Holbrook
Rationale: "John Edwards Holbrook... was considered by many to be the Father of Herpetology."[34][35]

Name: Peter Artedi
Rationale: "Far greater than either of these... was he who has been justly called the Father of Ichthyology, Petrus (Peter) Artedi (1705–1735)."[36]

Name: Edward Jenner
Rationale: Pioneered the concept of vaccines including creating the smallpox vaccine, the world's first vaccine (in 1796).[37][38][39][40]

Name: Élie Metchnikoff
Rationale: Research of phagocytosis by macrophages and microphages as a critical host–defense mechanism.[41][42][43][44][45][46][47]

Name: Paul Ehrlich
Rationale: Described the side–chain theory of antibody formation and the mechanisms of how antibodies neutralize toxins and induce bacterial lysis with the help of complement.[41]

Name: Erik Acharius
Rationale: "Erik Acharius, the father of lichenology..."[48]

Name: Louis Pasteur
Rationale: The first to microscopically observe micro–organisms in water and the first to see bacteria.

Name: Gopalasamudram Narayana Iyer Ramachandran
Rationale: Founded the [world's first?] molecular biophysics unit (1970).

Name: Francesco Redi
Rationale: The founder of experimental biology and the first person to challenge the theory of spontaneous generation by demonstrating that maggots come from eggs of flies.[53]

Name: Ronald A. Fisher, Sewall Wright, J. B. S. Haldane
Antonie van Leeuwenhoek
Rationale: First to produce precise, correct descriptions of protozoa.

Name: Carl Linnaeus
Rationale: Devised the system of naming living organisms that became universally accepted in the scientific world.

Name: Martinus Beijerinck
Rationale: Studies of agricultural microbiology and industrial microbiology that yielded fundamental discoveries.

Name: Democritus
Rationale: Founder of atomism in cosmology.

Name: Father Roger Boscovich
Rationale: First coherent description of atomic theory.

Name: John Dalton
Rationale: First scientific description of the atom as a building block for more complex structures.

Name: J. Robert Oppenheimer
Rationale: served as the director of the Manhattan Project's Los Alamos Laboratory during World War II. He is often called the "father of the atomic bomb" for his role in overseeing the development of the first nuclear weapons.

Name: Gilbert Lewis
Rationale: Thermodynamics and the Free Energy of Chemical Substances (1923) and Modern Thermodynamics by the Methods of Willard Gibbs (1933), which made a major contribution to the use of thermodynamics in chemistry.

Name: Antoine Lavoisier
Rationale: Elements of Chemistry (1787)

Name: Robert Boyle
Rationale: The Sceptical Chymist (1661)

Name: Jöns Berzelius
Rationale: Development of chemical nomenclature (1800s)

Name: John Dalton
Rationale: Revival of atomic theory (1803)

Name: Paul Anastas
Rationale: Design and manufacture of chemicals that are non–hazardous and environmentally benign.

Name: Otto Hahn
Rationale: Applied Radiochemistry (1936)

Name: Dmitri Mendeleev
Rationale: Arranged the sixty–six elements known at the time in order of atomic weight by periodic intervals (1869).

Name: Mikhail Lomonosov
Rationale: The first to read lectures in physical chemistry and coin the term (1752).

Name: Jacobus van 't Hoff
Rationale: Jacobus van 't Hoff is considered one of the founders of the discipline of physical chemistry. His work helped found the discipline as it is today.[67][68][69]

Name: Svante Arrhenius
Rationale: Devised much of the theoretical foundation for physical chemistry. On the Equilibrium of Heterogeneous Substances (1876), Thermodynamik chemischer Vorgange (1882).

Name: Wilhelm Ostwald
Rationale: "Wilhelm Ostwald is considered one of the founders of the discipline of physical chemistry..."[71]

Name: Hermann von Helmholtz
Rationale: [citation needed]

Name: August Kekulé
Rationale: Discovered the structure of the benzene ring (1865) and pioneered structural chemistry in general

Name: Victor Goldschmidt
Rationale: For developing the Goldschmidt classification of elements.

Name: Eratosthenes
Rationale: Eratosthenes was first to write the word Geography (from Geo– and –graphy, literally "writing about the Earth")

Name: Georgius Agricola
Rationale: Wrote the first book on physical geology, De Ortu et Causis Subterraneorum (1546)

Name: Nicolas Steno
Rationale: For setting down most of the principles of modern geology.

Name: James Hutton
Rationale: For formulating uniformitarianism and the Plutonic theory.

Name: Alfred Wegener
Rationale: [citation needed]

Name: Édouard–Alfred Martel
Rationale: Began the first systematic exploration of cave systems and promoted speleology as a field separate from geology.

Name: Henri Dutrochet
Rationale: Discovered osmosis

Name: Hermann von Helmholtz
Rationale: Explained hearing and vision.

Name: Christian Wilhelm Braune
Rationale: First to describe the methodology of human gait (walking).

Name: Luigi Galvani
Rationale: First to discover animal electricity through a series of experiments in 1780.

Name: Ibn al–Nafis
Rationale: Father of circulatory and cardiovascular physiology.[84][85][86]

Name: Aaron T. Beck
Rationale: "In developing ways to do this, Beck became the father of cognitive therapy, one of the most important developments in psychotherapy in the last 50 years."[87]

Name: Robert Ettinger
Rationale: 1962 book, The Prospect of Immortality[88]

Name: Pierre Fauchard
Rationale: Widely known for writing the first complete scientific description of dentistry, Le Chirurgien Dentiste.

Name: Emil du Bois–Reymond
Rationale: The discoverer of nerve action potential.

Name: Peter Safar
Rationale: Safar pioneered CPR, intensive–care units and developed standards for EMT, ambulance design and equipment.

Name: Frank Pantridge
Rationale: Pantridge: [91]

Name: John Snow
Rationale: Determining the cause of the 1854 Broad Street cholera outbreak with a combination of public interviews and mapping

Name: Vesalius
Rationale: De humani corporis fabrica (1543)

Name: Victor McKusick
Rationale: Mendelian Inheritance in Man (started publishing in 1966)

Name: Charaka[97]
Rationale: Wrote the Charaka Samhit? and founded the Ayurveda system of medicine.

Name: Hippocrates[98][99]
Rationale: Prescribed professional practices for physicians through the Hippocratic Oath.

Name: Harvey Cushing[100]
Rationale: Developed techniques that considerably reduced the risks involved with brain surgery in the early 20th century.[100]

Name: Justus von Liebig
Rationale: "Justus Von Liebig, the 'father of modern nutrition', developed the perfect infant food. It consisted of [...]"[101]

Name: Antoine–Laurent Lavoisier
Rationale: "In addition to being known as the Father of Modern Chemistry, Lavoisier is also considered the Father of Modern Nutrition, as the first to discover the metabolism that occurs inside the human body..."[102]

Name: Thomas Starzl[103]
Rationale: Performed the first human liver transplant and established the clinical utility of anti–rejection drugs including ciclosporin. Developed major advances in organ preservation, procurement and transplantation.

Name: Hugh Owen Thomas[104]
Rationale: He stressed the importance of rest in treatment and was responsible for many landmark contributions to orthopaedic surgery. He was especially celebrated for his design and use of splints; the famous Thomas knee splint was still in wide use at the end of World War II.

Name: Wilhelm Wundt[105]
Rationale: Founded the first laboratory for psychological research, thereby establishing psychology as a distinct science.[106] Wundt is also regarded as the father of experimental psychology.[107]

Name: Muhammad ibn Zakar?ya R?zi[108]
Rationale: Wrote The Diseases of Children, the first book to deal with pediatrics as an independent field.

Name: François Magendie
Rationale: Précis élementaire de Physiologie (1816)

Name: Bernarr Macfadden
Rationale: "It delighted the heart of our old friend Bernarr Macfadden, 'the Father of Physical Culture,' when we told him how much athletic activity and good sportsmanship had to do with the rehabilitation of boys."[109]

Name: Harold Gillies
Rationale: Wrote the Sushruta Samhita (ancient)

Name: Ernst Heinrich Weber
Rationale: Formulating the Weber–Fechner law in Elements of Psychophysics (1860).[115] This publication is regarded as the beginning of psychophysics.[116] Fechner also coined the term psychophysics.[117]

Name: Hubertus Strughold
Rationale: "After Wernher von Braun, he was the top Nazi scientist employed by the American government, and he was subsequently hailed by NASA as the 'father of space medicine'"[118]

Name: Sushruta[110][111]
Rationale: Wrote the Sushruta Samhita (878 CE?)

Name: Abu al–Qasim al–Zahrawi[119]
Rationale: Kitab al–Tasrif (1000 AD).

Name: Guy de Chauliac[120]
Rationale: Chirurgia magna

Name: Ambroise Paré
Rationale: Leader in surgical techniques, especially the treatment of wounds.[121]

Name: John Hunter
Rationale: Experimental, scientific approach to surgery.[122][123]

Name: Joseph Lister
Rationale: Use of carbolic acid as an antiseptic.[124][125]

Name: William Stewart Halsted
Rationale: Introduction of residency system in the United States.[126]

Name: Francisco de Vitoria
Rationale: Highly influential teacher and lecturer on commercial morality

Name: Thomas Cardinal Cajetan
Rationale: Recognised the effect of market expectations on the value of money

Name: Kenneth Arrow
Rationale: Created the field with his 1951 book Social Choice and Individual Values.

Name: John von Neumann
Rationale: Von Neumann and Morgenstern created the field with their 1944 book Theory of Games and Economic Behavior.

Name: Oskar Morgenstern
Rationale: Nash created the Nash equilibrium.

Name: Luca Pacioli
Rationale: Establisher of accounting and the first person to publish a work on bookkeeping.[209]

Name: Ibn Khaldun
Rationale: Publication: Muqaddimah (1370)

Name: Chanakya / Kautilya
Rationale: Publication: Arthashastra (400 BCE – 200 CE)

Name: Richard Cantillon
Rationale: First specific treatise on economics.

Name: Anders Chydenius
Rationale: The National Gain (1765), a pamphlet that included key ideas about free trade.[215]

Name: Adam Smith
Rationale: The Wealth of Nations (1776).

Name: Nicholas Georgescu–Roegen
Rationale: The Entropy Law and the Economic Process (1971)

Name: John Maynard Keynes
Rationale: Author of The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money and groundbreaking economist, Keynes spearheaded a revolution in economic thinking. Prior to Keynes, the general consensus among economists was that the economy was self–fixing. During the Great Depression, when people began to realize that the economy would not fix itself, Keynes proposed that the government needed to intervene to combat excessive boom and bust. This idea was the largest influence in U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.[222][223]

Name: Daniel Bernoulli
Rationale: Forerunner of the Tableau économique.[224]

Name: Nicole Oresme
Rationale: Oresme's De Moneta.

Name: Irving Fisher
Rationale: "Irving Fisher [...] spent his career studying questions about money and the economy – how money affects interest rates, how money affects inflation, and the impact of money on overall economic activity. For this work, he is regarded as the father of monetary economics."[226]

Name: Milton Friedman
Rationale: "[...] no less an authority than the University of Chicago's Milton Friedman, the father of monetary economics, [...]"[227]

Name: Muhammad Yunus
Rationale: Founded Grameen Bank

Name: Edward Lazear
Rationale: Published the first paper in the field.

Name: Ellen Swallow Richards
Rationale: Founded the American Association of Home Economics, currently the American Association of Family & Consumer Sciences. "Bringing science into the home, Richards hoped to '...attain the best physical, mental, and moral development' for the family, which she believed was the basic unit of civilization."[229]

Name: Galileo Galilei
Rationale: For systemic use of experimentation in science and contributions to scientific method, physics and observational astronomy

Name: Thales
Rationale: Attempted to explain natural phenomena without recourse to mythology

Rationale: His contributions to the field include vast quantities of information about the variety, structure, and behavior of animals
